did.head: Collection Overview

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: State University of New York at Buffalo. Music Library

did.abstract: Contains 6 cassette recordings of interviews conducted with collector J. Warren Perry and 2 VHS tapes of events in which he was featured.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Specified item], J. Warren Perry Interview Tapes, 1995-2002, Music Library, The State University of New York at Buffalo.

accessrestrict.head: Terms of Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials can be examined by qualified researchers in the Music Library during hours of operation during which Music Librarians are present. In order to insure access, researchers are advised to contact the Music Library in advance of visits.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Copyright for the materials in the collection does not reside with the Music Library. Therefore, patrons wishing to publish any item, or part of an item from this collection for any purpose, are responsible for securing requisite permissions.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Cassettes created by Music Library staff and students.

accruals.head: Accruals and Additions
accruals.p: No further accruals are expected to this collection.

note.p: Two copies of each cassette have been retained until it can be determined which copy is the original and preferred for digitizing.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Dr. J. Warren Perry was born in Richmond, Indiana in 1921. He earned his B.A. at DePauw University in 1944, his Master's at Northwestern University in 1952, and his Ph.D. at Northwestern in 1955. Dr. Perry has been on the faculties at the University of Illinois at Chicago, Northwestern Medical School, and the University of Chicago. He was also employed as deputy assistant commissioner for research and training in the Vocational Rehabilitation Administration at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in Washington, D.C. Dr. Perry is the founder of the School of Health Related Professions (now the School of Public Health and Health Professions) at the University at Buffalo, The State University of New York. He served as dean of the school from its founding in 1967 until 1977.

Dr. Perry devoted much of his life to supporting the arts. Before moving to Buffalo he was one of the founders of the Lyric Opera Company in Chicago. Since arriving in Buffalo Dr. Perry has served as chairman or board member for several local organizations, including the Buffalo Philharmonic, Community Music School, Theodore Roosevelt Inaugural National Historic Site, Artpark, and Friends of the Center for the Arts. The numerous awards granted to honor Dr. Perry's contributions to the community include the Buffalo Arts Councils' Supporter of the Arts award, the Buffalo Distinguished Citizen Award, and national Outstanding Philanthropist Award. Dr. Perry died August 5, 2010 in Buffalo.

J. Warren Perry was an avid collector of photographs and other artifacts related to music, especially opera and ballet. He worked for the Lyric Opera in Chicago as Director of the Committee on Education. He was interviewed in 1995 by Music Library students, Leah Maragliano and Kathy Blough.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Contains 6 cassette recordings of interviews conducted with collector J. Warren Perry and 2 VHS tapes of events in which he was featured.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in two series:

did.unittitle: Interview with J. Warren Perry tape 1, 10 May 1995
Interview with J. Warren Perry tape 2, 17 May 1995
Interview with J. Warren Perry tape 3, 17 May 1995
Interview with J. Warren Perry tape 4, 24 May 1995
Interview with J. Warren Perry tape 5, 24 May 1995, 31 May 1995
Interview with J. Warren Perry tape 6, 31 May 1995

relatedmaterial.head: Related Resources in the Music Library

defitem.label: J. Warren Perry Collection of Photographs, ca. 1910-1971 Mus. Arc. 3.1
defitem.item: A collection of 2110 photographs, chiefly of opera singers and productions, with additional photographs of conductors, performers, ensembles, and concert halls.
